questions.question: What is Mandakini?

questions.question: Define a galaxy.
questions.answer: A galaxy is a large group of innumerable stars, planetary systems, dust and gases bound together by gravity.

questions.question: Name the galaxy in which our solar system is located.
questions.answer: Our solar system is located in the Milky Way galaxy.

questions.question: What is the Local Group?
questions.answer: The Local Group is a cluster of galaxies that includes the Milky Way and nearby galaxies.

questions.question: Name the galaxy closest to the Milky Way.
questions.answer: The Andromeda galaxy is closest to the Milky Way.

questions.question: Name any two components found in the Milky Way.
questions.answer: Nebulae and clouds of dust are components found in the Milky Way.

questions.question: Why is a telescope useful for sky observation?
questions.answer: A telescope helps observe distant celestial objects clearly.

questions.question: On what basis are galaxies classified?
questions.answer: Galaxies are classified based on their shape.

questions.question: Name any two types of galaxies.
questions.answer: Spiral galaxies and elliptical galaxies are two types of galaxies.

questions.question: What is a star?
questions.answer: A star is a self-luminous celestial body that emits its own light and heat.

questions.question: Where are stars formed?
questions.answer: Stars are formed in nebulae.

questions.question: What determines the colour of a star?
questions.answer: The colour of a star is determined by its temperature.

questions.question: What are red giant stars?
questions.answer: Red giants are stars with very large size and high luminance but comparatively lower temperature.

questions.question: What are binary stars?
questions.answer: Binary stars are two stars that revolve around each other.

questions.question: What are variable stars?
questions.answer: Variable stars are stars whose brightness changes periodically.

questions.question: Who proved that galaxies exist beyond the Milky Way?
questions.answer: Edwin Hubble proved that galaxies exist beyond the Milky Way.

questions.question: Name the telescope launched in 1990 by NASA.
questions.answer: The Hubble Space Telescope was launched in 1990 by NASA.

questions.question: What is the solar system?
questions.answer: The solar system consists of the Sun and all celestial bodies that revolve around it.

questions.question: Name the celestial bodies included in the solar system.
questions.answer: Planets, satellites, asteroids, comets and meteors are included in the solar system.

questions.question: Which planet is closest to the Sun?
questions.answer: Mercury is the planet closest to the Sun.

questions.question: Which planet is the hottest in the solar system?
questions.answer: Venus is the hottest planet in the solar system.

questions.question: Why is Mars called the Red Planet?
questions.answer: Mars is called the Red Planet due to the presence of iron in its soil.

questions.question: Name the largest planet in the solar system.
questions.answer: Jupiter is the largest planet in the solar system.

questions.question: Which planet is famous for its rings?
questions.answer: Saturn is famous for its rings.

questions.question: Which planet appears to roll on its orbit?
questions.answer: Uranus appears to roll on its orbit due to its tilted axis.

questions.question: Which planet has extremely high-speed winds?
questions.answer: Neptune has extremely high-speed winds.

questions.question: What is a satellite?
questions.answer: A satellite is a celestial body that revolves around a planet.

questions.question: Which planet does not have any natural satellite?
questions.answer: Mercury does not have any natural satellite.

questions.question: What is the asteroid belt?
questions.answer: The asteroid belt is a region between Mars and Jupiter where numerous asteroids revolve around the Sun.

questions.question: What is a dwarf planet?
questions.answer: A dwarf planet is a celestial body that revolves around the Sun but does not clear its orbital path.

questions.question: What are comets made of?
questions.answer: Comets are made of ice, dust and gases.

questions.question: Why does a comet develop a tail?
questions.answer: A comet develops a tail due to the conversion of ice into gas when it comes near the Sun.

questions.question: What are long-period comets?
questions.answer: Long-period comets take more than 200 years to complete one revolution around the Sun.

questions.question: Which comet reappears every 76 years?
questions.answer: Halley’s comet reappears every 76 years.

questions.question: What is a meteor?
questions.answer: A meteor is a celestial body that appears as a streak of light when it burns in the Earth’s atmosphere.

questions.question: What are meteorites?
questions.answer: Meteorites are meteors that reach the Earth’s surface without burning completely.

questions.question: Name the lake formed due to a meteorite impact in India.
questions.answer: Lonar Lake was formed due to a meteorite impact.

questions.question: Who proposed the ‘dirty snowball’ theory of comets?
questions.answer: Fred Whipple proposed the ‘dirty snowball’ theory of comets.

questions.question: Why do small meteors burn up in the atmosphere?
questions.answer: Small meteors burn up due to friction with air.

questions.question: Which planet has a day longer than its year?
questions.answer: Venus has a day longer than its year.

questions.question: Name the inner planets of the solar system.
questions.answer: Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars are the inner planets.

questions.question: What are outer planets?
questions.answer: Outer planets are large planets with gaseous outer layers located beyond the asteroid belt.

questions.question: Why is Earth suitable for life?
questions.answer: Earth has suitable temperature, water, atmosphere and a magnetic field that support life.

questions.question: Which planet has the maximum number of satellites?
questions.answer: Jupiter has the maximum number of satellites.

questions.question: Why does the Moon not have an atmosphere?
questions.answer: The Moon has weak gravity, so it cannot retain an atmosphere.

questions.question: Why do we always see the same side of the Moon?
questions.answer: Because the Moon’s rotation period is equal to its revolution period around the Earth.

questions.question: Which celestial body appears with a bright tail in the sky?
questions.answer: A comet appears with a bright tail in the sky.

questions.question: What scientific attitude should be adopted while studying celestial events?
questions.answer: A scientific attitude without superstition should be adopted.

questions.question: Why is observation important in the study of astronomy?
questions.answer: Observation helps in understanding the nature, movement and characteristics of celestial bodies.

questions.question: Why is the Milky Way visible as a continuous band across the night sky?
questions.answer: Because our solar system lies within the Milky Way and we view its dense plane edge-on, making stars appear as a continuous band.

questions.question: How does the classification of galaxies based on shape help astronomers?
questions.answer: It helps astronomers understand the structure, evolution, and motion of stars within different galaxies.

questions.question: Why was the discovery of galaxies beyond the Milky Way significant?
questions.answer: It expanded the understanding of the universe by proving that the Milky Way is only one of many galaxies.

questions.question: How does a telescope improve the study of distant celestial objects?
questions.answer: A telescope collects more light and magnifies distant objects, allowing detailed observation.

questions.question: Why are nebulae called stellar nurseries?
questions.answer: Because new stars are formed from gas and dust present in nebulae.

questions.question: How does temperature influence the colour of stars?
questions.answer: Hotter stars appear bluish-white, while cooler stars appear red due to differences in surface temperature.

questions.question: Why do red giant stars have high luminosity despite lower temperatures?
questions.answer: Their extremely large size compensates for lower temperature, resulting in high luminosity.

questions.question: How do binary stars help in determining stellar masses?
questions.answer: By studying their orbital motion, astronomers can calculate the mass of each star.

questions.question: Why is the solar system considered a part of a galaxy?
questions.answer: Because the Sun and its planets are gravitationally bound within the Milky Way galaxy.

questions.question: How does Mercury’s proximity to the Sun affect its motion?
questions.answer: Its close distance results in a faster orbital speed around the Sun.

questions.question: Why is Venus hotter than Mercury despite being farther from the Sun?
questions.answer: Venus has a dense atmosphere that traps heat, causing extremely high temperatures.

questions.question: How does the presence of iron in Martian soil influence its appearance?
questions.answer: Iron oxidizes and gives Mars its characteristic red colour.

questions.question: Why does Jupiter have a strong gravitational influence in the solar system?
questions.answer: Its very large mass creates a strong gravitational pull on nearby objects.

questions.question: How do Saturn’s rings enhance understanding of planetary systems?
questions.answer: They provide insight into the distribution and motion of particles around planets.

questions.question: Why does Uranus appear to roll along its orbit?
questions.answer: Because its axis is highly tilted, nearly parallel to its orbital plane.

questions.question: How do high-speed winds affect Neptune’s atmosphere?
questions.answer: They create intense storms and dynamic atmospheric patterns.

questions.question: Why do some planets have many satellites while others have none?
questions.answer: Differences in gravitational strength and formation history affect satellite capture.

questions.question: How does the asteroid belt indicate early solar system formation?
questions.answer: It contains remnants of material that never formed into a planet.

questions.question: Why was Pluto reclassified as a dwarf planet?
questions.answer: Because it does not clear its orbital path of other objects.

questions.question: How does the composition of comets explain their changing appearance?
questions.answer: Ice vaporizes near the Sun, forming a glowing head and tail.

questions.question: Why do comet tails always point away from the Sun?
questions.answer: Solar radiation and solar wind push the tail away from the Sun.

questions.question: How do long-period comets differ in origin from short-period comets?
questions.answer: They originate from distant regions of the solar system and take longer to orbit the Sun.

questions.question: Why do most meteors burn up before reaching Earth’s surface?
questions.answer: Friction with Earth’s atmosphere generates intense heat that burns them.

questions.question: How does the formation of Lonar Lake support meteorite impact theory?
questions.answer: Its circular shape and geological features indicate impact by a meteorite.

questions.question: Why is scientific explanation preferred over superstition in astronomy?
questions.answer: Scientific explanations are based on observation, evidence, and logical reasoning.

questions.question: How does Earth’s magnetic field contribute to life on the planet?
questions.answer: It protects Earth from harmful solar radiation.

questions.question: Why is Earth uniquely suited for life among known planets?
questions.answer: It has suitable temperature, water, atmosphere, and protective magnetic field.

questions.question: How does the equal rotation and revolution period of the Moon affect observation?
questions.answer: It causes the same side of the Moon to always face the Earth.

questions.question: Why is the study of the universe important for scientific development?
questions.answer: It enhances understanding of natural laws and the origin of celestial bodies.

questions.question: How does observation of the night sky encourage scientific curiosity?
questions.answer: It motivates questioning, exploration, and understanding of natural phenomena.

questions.question: Why are galaxies considered building blocks of the universe?
questions.answer: Because they contain stars, planetary systems, and matter that make up the universe.

questions.question: How does gravity govern the structure of galaxies?
questions.answer: Gravity holds stars and planetary systems together within galaxies.

questions.question: Why is the solar system stable over long periods?
questions.answer: Gravitational balance between the Sun and planets maintains stable orbits.

questions.question: How does planetary motion support the heliocentric model?
questions.answer: Planets revolve around the Sun, confirming the Sun-centered system.

questions.question: Why is classification essential in the study of celestial bodies?
questions.answer: It helps organize information and understand similarities and differences.

questions.question: How do outer planets differ from inner planets in composition?
questions.answer: Outer planets are gaseous while inner planets are rocky.

questions.question: Why is continuous observation important in astronomy?
questions.answer: It helps detect changes and movements of celestial objects over time.

questions.question: How do technological advancements improve space observation?
questions.answer: They allow clearer, deeper, and more accurate observation of space.

questions.question: Why are comets considered time capsules of the solar system?
questions.answer: They contain primitive material from early solar system formation.

questions.question: How does studying meteors contribute to understanding Earth’s safety?
questions.answer: It helps assess impact risks and atmospheric protection.

questions.question: Why does space appear dark despite the presence of many stars?
questions.answer: Because stars are very distant and light does not fill all of space uniformly.

questions.question: How does Earth’s atmosphere influence observation of space?
questions.answer: It absorbs and scatters some radiation, limiting ground-based observations.

questions.question: Why are space telescopes more effective than ground telescopes?
questions.answer: They operate above Earth’s atmosphere, avoiding distortion.

questions.question: How does understanding planetary motion help in space missions?
questions.answer: It allows accurate navigation and trajectory planning.

questions.question: Why is scientific temper essential while studying astronomical events?
questions.answer: It promotes rational thinking and avoids misconceptions.

questions.question: How does astronomy contribute to technological progress?
questions.answer: It drives innovation in optics, communication, and data analysis.

questions.question: Why is comparative study of planets useful?
questions.answer: It helps understand Earth’s uniqueness and planetary evolution.

questions.question: How does the study of galaxies change our perception of Earth’s place in the universe?
questions.answer: It shows that Earth is a small part of a vast universe.

questions.question: Why is the universe described as dynamic rather than static?
questions.answer: Because celestial bodies are constantly moving and evolving.

questions.question: How does learning about the universe encourage scientific thinking?
questions.answer: It fosters observation, reasoning, and evidence-based understanding.
